channel.title: Articles | Mail Online
channel.description: MailOnline - get the latest breaking news, showbiz & celebrity photos, sport news & rumours, viral videos and top stories from MailOnline, Daily Mail and Mail on Sunday newspapers.

item.title: Thomas Lane, one of the four Minneapolis cops charged in George Floyd's death, posts bail
item.description: Thomas Lane, 37, who had been held in lieu of $750,000 cash bail, was freed shortly before 4:10pm. from the Hennepin County jail, a spokesperson from the Sheriff's Office said.

item.title: Shocking footage shows Hackney police officer wrestle with suspect as passersby take selfies
item.description: Shocking scenes in Hackney on Wednesday afternoon show a police officer wrestling on the ground with a suspect, as passersby dance and take selfies around them.

item.title: Premier League to hold minute's silence before matches in honour of the NHS workers
item.description: EXCLUSIVE BY MIKE KEEGAN: Starting with the Wednesday night fixtures and continuing into the first weekend, players and officials will gather — socially distanced — before kick-off.

item.title: Junk food industry shares the blame for Britain's Covid-19 disaster, scientists argue
item.description: Statistics show that six out of 10 people who have died of coronavirus in Britain have been obesity and critics say the food industry must shoulder some of the blame.

item.title: Boris Johnson pledges 'massive' summer school 'catch-up operation' to help pupils
item.description: Boris Johnson has announced there will be a 'big summer of catch up' for pupils who have missed out on their education amid the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: Madeleine McCann suspect beat up British ex-girlfriend in jealous rage
item.description: The victim, from Berkshire,first met Brueckner in the Algarve town of Lagos in late 2003 at a restaurant they were both working at.

item.title: Kids in Denmark are thriving at school after ditching the two-metre rule, writes Morten Olsen
item.description: When it was announced that schools in Denmark were reopening - five weeks after lockdown began - many parents were anxious about sending their children back into education.

item.title: I don't want our wild lockdown sex to end
item.description: Suzan Mitchell reveals how the UK lockdown has made her sex life better. She revealed how her sex quota with her husband Michael for this month now eclipses that of the last two years.

item.title: Fury as Sinn Fein 'blocks payments to victims of IRA bombings'
item.description: The Government has accused Sinn Fein of holding up implementation of the Troubles Pension because it wants former prisoners to receive the money too. Whitehall calls it an 'absolute betrayal.'

item.title: Chief Medical Officer Chris Whitty warns stay-at-home rules could return in winter
item.description: He pointed out that the virus 'transmits more easily indoors' and suggested the infection rates could start to rise again as temperatures dropped and people migrated inside.

item.title: Coronavirus UK: Boris Johnson announces 'support bubble' policy
item.description: From Saturday two households can form 'support bubbles' that can meet indoors and stay overnight. But one of the two must be either a single person living alone or a single parent with children.

item.title: MPs pile pressure on Boris Johnson to cut 2-metre social distancing rule to one-metre restriction
item.description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson was under huge pressure on Wednesday night to cut the two-metre social distancing rule to just one metres as MPs fear tens of thousands of businesses could go bust.

item.title: JK Rowling makes statement after 'transphobia' accusations
item.description: The Harry Potter author appeared to confirm for the first time that she had suffered domestic abuse, describing her first marriage to Portuguese journalism student Jorge Arantas as 'violent'.

item.title: Cops confirm two sets of human remains were found at Lori Vallow's husband's home
item.description: Rexburg Police confirmed on Wednesday that two sets of remains were discovered on Chad Daybell's property in Salem, Idaho, during a search for the missing kids the day before.

item.title: Hertfordshire police arrive at home of museum curator who tweeted how to destroy bronze statues
item.description: Police arrived at the home of Madeline Odent in Hertfordshire today, but got no answer after knocking at her door. Statues have been targeted during Black Lives Matter protests.

item.title: Black Lives Matter protesters who tore down Edward Colston statue 'are likely to escape prosecution'
item.description: The monument was toppled during a Black Lives Matter protest on Sunday, but police have not made any arrests - despite the moment being recorded on film.

item.title: JFK's rosary beads and Jackie O's fabrics up for auction
item.description: The Kennedy family's memorabilia is being auctioned off today by University Archives in Westport, Connecticut.

item.title: A fall down the stairs ruined my looks... then 'nature's facelift' helped heal me
item.description: Melanie Cable-Alexander, from Somerset, reveals how four years ago she fell down the stairs after one foot became trapped in the other's trouser leg. She said her chin took the force of the fall.

item.title: 'Put Post chiefs in dock for this gross injustice': MPs call for prosecutions over IT scandal
item.description: Up to 960 postmasters were wrongfully convicted of fraud, theft and false accounting after a glitch with their Horizon IT system made it appear like cash had vanished from their tills.

item.title: Prince Harry, Meghan Markle and Archie 'spoke to Prince Philip to wish him a happy 99th birthday'
item.description: Royal expert Carolyn Durand took to Twitter to claim Prince Harry and Meghan Markle will speak to Prince Philip on his 99th birthday - but unlike other royals they opted against posting a public tribute.

item.title: Oliver Dowden 'wouldn't have taken Little Britain off iPlayer'
item.description: The Culture Secretary Oliver Dowden has told ITV's Peston he 'wouldn't be inclined' to pull Little Britain from streaming services. It came after BBC iPlayer, BritBox and Netflix dropped the show.

item.title: JANET STREET-PORTER: Frankly, my dear, I don't give a damn how many statues you topple
item.description: JANET STREET-PORTER: After protestors toppled a statue of man few outside Bristol had probably ever heard of, I was left with just one question; why stop at one?

item.title: Mum has died of a broken heart. Yousef's killer should have TWO lives on his conscience
item.description: Debbie Makki, from Greater Manchester, was forced not only to suffer the agony of her son, 17, being stabbed but to watch as the boy accused of killing him was cleared of murder and manslaughter.

item.title: How middle class is YOUR mango?
item.description: There is a glut of mangoes set to arrive in the UK as lots have been left to ripen without the demand from restaurants as the industry has been in lockdown and are now offered direct to consumers.

item.title: From red carpet to real life...SUSANNA REID
item.description: British presenter Susanna Reid reflects on following the Covid-19 rules. She also talks about her time in Bristol where she went to university 30 years ago and her new maxi dress orders.

item.title: Can the beauty counter ever recover its magic?
item.description: Beauty emporiums are set to open their doors once more from Monday in the UK. Whether you're purchasing High Street or high end, shopping for make-up and skincare will now be strikingly different.

item.title: Two sisters found dead at London beauty spot were stabbed 'multiple times'
item.description: Nicole Smallman (pictured), 27, and Bibaa Henry, 46, were found in Fryent Country Park in Wembley on Sunday. A post-mortem gave the cause of death for both women as stab wounds.

item.title: Owners of Elizabethan manor house move entire home up Sudbury hill to new location
item.description: John and Angela Hodge simply could not face leaving Ballingdon Hall, their 16th-century Grade II-listed Elizabethan manor house in Sudbury, so made the audacious call to just take it with them.

item.title: Former co-worker tells how George Floyd and Derek Chauvin 'bumped heads' while working at nightclub
item.description: David Pinney (left), who worked with George Floyd and Derek Chauvin at a nightclub in Minneapolis said the two men 'bumped heads', which had a lot to do with the cop being 'extremely aggressive'.

item.title: Everyday Ageism: FEMAIL columnist CHRISTA D'SOUZA
item.description: Christa D'souza asks if you find yourself giving the elderly an extra-wide berth now lockdown has been eased. The UK columnist said she watched the everyday ageism play out in her local Co-op.

item.title: Is it sexist against women to keep public loos shut?
item.description: Femail writers Saska Graville and Linda Kelsey debate if it is sexist against women to keep public loos shut. Former Cosmo editor said as far as she is concerned it is a gender-neutral issue.

item.title: Twenty-five reasons to be GLAD you can't go abroad
item.description: Official advice is to avoid non-essential travel and many will be forfeiting fortnights in the sun and European getaways for a staycation instead. Here are 25 reasons to be glad you cannot go abroad.

item.title: Henry Deedes: Boris Johnson and Keir Starmer were two budgies squabbling over a crumb of cuttlefish
item.description: Over seven long minutes Prime Minister Boris Johnson and Leader of the Opposition Sir Keir Starmer went at each other - and how. Gnawing, jabbing, poking one another.

item.title: Heroic nurses who put the needs of those in their care before their own families
item.description: Two mothers, both frontline workers, chose to isolate themselves from their children for several months in order to protect the vulnerable people who depend on them during the UK lockdown.

item.title: Men 'create more greenhouse gas emissions than women'
item.description: The transportation habits of men may account for more greenhouse gas emissions than women, according to a new study from New Zealand, which examined transport data for 50,000 residents.

item.title: Coronavirus UK: Death toll hits 41,000 with 245 new fatalities
item.description: Department of Health figures show the official number of victims has now topped 41,000 but other grim statistics yesterday revealed the actual number of deaths is closer to the 52,000-mark.

item.title: Widespread face mask use could shrink `R´ and stop second wave
item.description: Modelling by the universities of Cambridge and Greenwich found if half of Brits wore face coverings in public it would prevent the crisis from spiralling back out of control.

item.title: Stolen Banksy tribute to Paris terror victims found in farmhouse
item.description: The artwork, which depicted a sorrowful girl in mourning painted on emergency doors of the famous Bataclan concert hall in Paris, was cut out and snatched in January 2019.

item.title: 78 statues and monuments at risk of being torn down by 'Topple The Racists' campaign
item.description: A website called 'Topple The Racists' has identified 78 landmarks of colonialists, politicians and kings that they say need to be removed because of their alleged involvement in the slave trade.

item.title: Influencers wear BLACKFACE to 'support' Black Lives Matter
item.description: Instagrammers have shared photos in brown makeup accompanied by anti-racism captions. They're from the UAE, Lebanon, Philippines, Germany, Poland, Algeria, and Turkey.

item.title: Has the tomb of Cleopatra FINALLY been found?
item.description: Archaeologists leading a dig in Egypt believe Cleopatra is buried at a temple called Taposiris Magna, just outside of Alexandria, alongside Roman lover and general Mark Anthony.

item.title: Coronavirus UK: Earlier lockdown could have halved deaths
item.description: The Prime Minister struggled under a barrage of questions at tonight's Downing Street press conference after Professor Neil Ferguson's bombshell revelation to MPs this afternoon.

item.title: Ant and Dec issue apology for 'impersonating people of colour' on Saturday Night Takeaway
item.description: Ant and Dec have issued an apology to their Twitter followers for 'impersonating people of colour' during 'comedy' sketches on Saturday Night Takeaway.

item.title: Liverpool mayor refuses to change name of Penny Lane after claims it is linked to slaver
item.description: Liverpool Mayor Joe Anderson said there is 'no evidence' to support the claim that Penny Lane - made famous by The Beatles' song of the same name - is linked to slave ship owner James Penny.

item.title: Boyfriend heard his girlfriend's harrowing screams as she was killed in horrific car crash
item.description: Chloe Lloyd was driving home with her daughter and speaking to her partner via hands-free mobile when her Vauxhall Astra left the A35 near Poole, Dorset and crashed into a tree.

item.title: Tracey Cox reveals what it's like to be in a sexless relationship
item.description: Tracey Cox spoke to people in sexless relationships to find out what it's like - inlcuding one British woman, 29, who's devastated, while another wife, 39, says she's perfectly happy.

item.title: Now 130 Labour councils draw up hit-list of statues with colonial ties
item.description: Sir Thomas Guy helped set up the hospital near London Bridge in 1721 having made his fortune as a major shareholder of a company selling slaves to the Spanish Colonies.

item.title: Leonardo da Vinci's 'Vitruvian Man' close to modern proportions
item.description: Leonardo da Vinci's 'Vitruvian Man' was sketched in 1490 and is his depiction of the ideal man. Experts found the measurements of today's man are within 10% of da Vinci's estimates.

item.title: Coronavirus 'could be up to four times LESS deadly than feared'
item.description: An expert at Stanford University in California suggested the true death rate of the coronavirus is around 0.25 per cent, meaning the UK's 51,000 deaths suggest 20million have had the virus.

item.title: Netflix subscribers claim hit film The Help has a 'white saviour' narrative
item.description: Social media users from across the world have blasted Netflix US for streaming historical drama The Help amid ongoing protests. Many argue the 2011 film has a 'white saviour' narrative.

item.title: Dozens of migrants arrive in Dover after they were picked up in three small boats
item.description: The group, who were picked up by a French patrol boat at 6.35am after attempting to cross the Channel in a make-shift vessel, had used shovels as oars.

item.title: Madeleine suspect is at centre of a legal row over blunders that freed him from jail two years ago
item.description: The revelations come as Brueckner, 43, is at the centre of a major row in Germany over whether he should be freed as it emerged he was released from prison in 2018 and allowed to travel.

item.title: Bone bird carving found at tip may be 'China's oldest work of art'
item.description: A tiny 13,300-year-old bone carving of bird unearthed at a rubbish tip has been hailed as 'China's oldest work of art' by an international team of scientists.

item.title: Revealed, the best way to find out your blood type
item.description: A study by the genetic testing website 23AndMe suggested that people with O-type blood appear to be more likely to get diagnosed with the coronavirus, so here's how to find out your blood type.

item.title: Police have ruled out Christian Brueckner as suspect in rape of Irish holiday rep
item.description: Friedrich Fülscher, who represents Christian Brueckner told German media: 'How can a person, who is isolated in a prison and whom half the world's population accuses of the worst crimes, be?'

item.title: Patient, 34, dies after judge ruled he had right to refuse permanent stoma bag
item.description: Mr Justice Hayden ruled earlier this month that the man, who was in intensive care at Barnsley hospital, could be allowed to die after considering evidence at a virtual hearing in the Court of Protection.

item.title: Coronavirus UK: 77% cases originated in Spain, France and Italy
item.description: Research by the universities of Edinburgh and Oxford traced the last common ancestors of more than 1,300 samples of the coronavirus collected in the UK, finding most linked to Europe.

item.title: Anthony Joshua and Tyson Fury reach a 'financial agreement' for TWO world-title fights
item.description: Discussions over a mouthwatering Battle of Britain, which would see all four major world heavyweight titles on the line, has been ongoing for months.

item.title: Coral islands like the Maldives could survive sea level rise
item.description: An international team of scientists, led by the University of Plymouth, found coral reef islands, such as the Maldives, could naturally adapt to survive surging water levels.

item.title: Coronavirus: Air travel has been a 'major' driver in spread
item.description: A report by the Institute for Economics and Peace said that international flights - on which the UK never placed a ban - had 'facilitated contagion' of the coronavirus around the world.

item.title: Eight years' jail for socialite who sent indecent photos of child
item.description: Katie Weeks, 36, lived a glamorous lifestyle close to the millionaire's enclave in Poole, Dorset, and was married to the director of a successful interior design agency. She has been jailed for nine years.

item.title: Opposition to Baroness Scotland Commonwealth reappointment
item.description: A leaked letter from Boris Johnson to other leaders said a call for Baroness Scotland (pictured) to be granted a second term as secretary general amid the coronavirus crisis had been turned down.

item.title: Toppled statue of slaver Edward Colston WILL be fished out of Bristol docks
item.description: The monument to Edward Colston will be fished out of the river and placed in a museum in Bristol, the city's Mayor Marvin Rees has confirmed today.

item.title: NHS nurse, 62, dies of coronavirus after sitting with surgery patient who later tested positive
item.description: Dominga David worked at University Hospital Llandough when she was infected. She was sent home on March 31 and died on May 26, South Wales Central coroner's court in Pontypridd heard.

item.title: Have you been microwaving your popcorn wrong?
item.description: If you place a bag of popcorn into the microwave before 'preheating' the microwave itself then you're not getting the best results from your corn kernels.

item.title: Coronavirus: US study says tests miss a fifth of infections
item.description: A new study from Johns Hopkins Medicine found that if coronavirus tests were administered four days after a person became infected, the false-negative rate was about 67%.

item.title: Incredible story of the 'true hero of the Titanic' who saved dozens of women and children
item.description: Harold Lowe was a hero of the Titanic and some of his treasured belongings are now going on sale for £60,000. His whistle, ceremonial hat and certificate of competency are among the items.

item.title: Anti-racism campaigners call for 'The 'Black Boy' pubs across Britain to be renamed
item.description: Calls are being made for pubs in Britain called 'The Black Boy' to be renamed amid growing anti-racism protests by the Black Lives Matter movement.

item.title: Pedestrian killed by hit-and-run driver during police chase in horror smash in Wakefield
item.description: The motorist crashed into pedestrian Andrew Kitson, 44, (pictured) while he was chased by police through Wakefield in West Yorkshire yesterday afternoon.

item.title: Study shows 70 per cent of people are more likely to listen to expert advice after COVID
item.description: The survey - commissioned by UK-based communications agency Higginson Strategy - also found that women are more likely to heed expert guidance.

item.title: Touching moment father surprises his hazmat suit-wearing children
item.description: Ben Shard, 36, visited his three children at the home where they live with his former partner, Claire Sharman, 31, in Sarnau, Wales, and enjoyed a tearful reunion in the front garden.

item.title: 6ft 7in woman signed by modelling agency recalls bullying
item.description: Naomi Lovell, 22, from Doncaster, Yorkshire, says she receives unwanted sexual attention on social media because of her striking stature but now feels more confident after signing to Ugly Models.

item.title: Calculating the speed of solar eruptions could help protect astronauts and satellites
item.description: Currently forecasters focus on the size of coronal mass ejections coming from the Sun, rather than their speed, when warning of any possible impact they might have.

item.title: Riots could break out in UK this summer, SAGE adviser warns
item.description: Professor Clifford Stott - a member of Number 10's SAGE panel - said urgent efforts are needed by police forces to quell any potential unrest in the neighbourhoods they serve.

item.title: Revealed! People who REALLY aren't handling lockdown well
item.description: A series of photos taken by people from across the globe, which have been collated online by GoSocial, prove that not everyone is handling lockdown well.

item.title: Secondary schools reopen in Spain, Netherlands and South Africa
item.description: Switzerland and the Netherlands have achieved what Britain hoped to do, sending all primary-age pupils back - saying that the risk of young children spreading the disease is low.

item.title: Couple transform dilapidated church bought for £85K into stunning contemporary home
item.description: Hannah Lewis, 29, an occupational therapist from West Cumbria, and her partner Wayne purchased the old church in 2015 at a cost of £85,000 and began renovating it in 2016.

item.title: Met Office issues severe weather warning for flooding
item.description: Forecasters warn up to 70mm (2.75 ins) of rain could fall in six hours later today, with motorists urged to take care on the roads across Cornwall, Devon, Plymouth and Wales.

item.title: How COULD schools go back? Calls for 'furlough-style' plan to get children back in the classroom
item.description: Boris Johnson is under pressure after plans for all primary school children to return for a month of school before the summer break in July were abandoned yesterday, with no clear way forward.

item.title: PIERS MORGAN: Defunding the police is a bats**** crazy idea that will help Trump get re-elected
item.description: In the past two weeks, we've seen the very worst of police work in America, and some of the very best. The worst manifested itself with the slow, contemptuous murder of George Floyd.

item.title: Britain's Brightest Celebrity Family: Scarlett Moffatt takes on Strictly star AJ Pritchard
item.description: Gogglebox star Scarlett Moffatt takes on Strictly star Aj Pritchard in a the third episode of ITV's new 'Britain's Brightest Celebrity Family', which airs on Thursday evening.

item.title: Fantastic Beasts star Eddie Redmayne hits out at J.K. Rowling
item.description: Eddie Redmayne has become the latest star to hit out at JK Rowling over her comments surrounding transgender people.

item.title: HBO Max temporarily pulls Gone With The Wind after accusations it 'glorifies the antebellum south'
item.description: Gone With The Wind has been removed temporarily by HBO Max from its streaming service in the light of widespread unease at America's racial legacy. The film will return 'with historical context'.

item.title: Russian lion cub had legs broken 'so it could not escape while tourists posed for photos with it'
item.description: Vladimir Putin was so shocked that he personally ordered a criminal probe into the cruelty Simba the lion experienced, who was just a few weeks old when snatched from his mother.

item.title: Porn stars turn up unannounced in hilarious online safety campaign
item.description: The clip is part of the New Zealand government's efforts to get parents to talk to their children about real-life relationships and the importance of consent with a sexual partner.

item.title: Plucky buyer who wrote to owners of a house she liked reveals how she got it
item.description: Social worker Sally Deakin, 35, from Doncaster, spotted the five-bed terrace on Lawn Avenue in 2017 and decided to ask the owners - via a letter through the door - if they'd sell.

item.title: Police launch urgent search for two missing sisters, aged 11 and 9
item.description: Matilda Hooligan, 11, and her nine-year-old sister Scarlett, were last seen at their home in Southport, Merseyside, on May 31. They are believed to be with a member of their family.

item.title: A fifth of the UK's partially deaf who have NHS hearing aids do not bother to wear them
item.description: Researchers from the University of Manchester interviewed 16,000 people with some degree of hearing loss about their use of NHS funded equipment.

item.title: Spain flights to be more expensive with coronavirus safety plans
item.description: The announcement has sparked concerns of higher air fares and the potential collapse of embattled airlines.

item.title: Police chief constable 'took the knee' at a Black Lives Matter event
item.description: Alan Pughsley of Kent Police and other officers joined the socially distanced group of more than 50 people in Gravesens last Thursday after George Floyd died in Minneapolis on May 25.

item.title: Widow's late husband was diagnosed with a brain tumour six WEEKS after their first date
item.description: Speaking on This Morning, Sara Challice, 49 from London, revealed how she became ill while caring for Neal, because she wasn't looking after herself and became isolated from family and friends.

item.title: Boris Johnson hints contact tracing figures might FINALLY be released tomorrow
item.description: The much delayed operation was rolled out at the start of June along with a 25,000-strong army of staff but ministers have so far refused to release data on how well it is working.

item.title: Aldi is first UK supermarket to stock coronavirus face masks
item.description: Aldi is selling reusable face masks for £4.99. They are available in one size, are double layered, ideal for covering both mouth and nose, and are made from machine-washable cotton.

item.title: NATO drills get underway in the Baltic Sea
item.description: NATO's annual training exercise in the Baltic Sea is now underway, with 28 ships and aircraft on manoeuvers for 10 days alongside 3,000 troops from 19 countries including the UK, US and Germany.

item.title: F35B Lightning jets from historic squadron land on £3bn aircraft carrier HMS Queen Elizabeth
item.description: F-35 Lightning Jets from historic 'Dambusters' squadron have landed on HMS Queen Elizabeth for the first time as the jets completed a series of time trials on the aircraft carrier near Portsmouth.

item.title: One Show presenter Amol Rajan wins huge praise over his report on Little Britain and racism
item.description: Viewers said the Media Editor's monologue left them 'in awe' after he updated news anchor Huw Edwards on the news that Little Britain had been removed from Netflix, BBC iPlayer and BritBox.

item.title: Inside the Indian tribe once feared for decapitating their rivals and displaying severed body parts
item.description: A series of striking photographs reveals the distinctive facial features of the frail Konyak people, sporting nose plugs, brandishing spears, and wearing jewellery crafted from dead animals.

item.title: Meghan Markle and Prince Harry 'shifting focus' to support BLM
item.description: The Duke, 35, and Duchess of Sussex, 38, are 'shifting their focus' and will be 'doing a lot more work' to support Black Lives Matter, royal expert Katie Nicholl told Entertainment Tonight.

item.title: Rishi Sunak 'believes school closures as damaging as credit crunch'
item.description: Chancellor Rishi Sunak is believed to be among the most hawkish in government on the need to reopen schools.

item.title: Police find body of woman, 19, near footpath at popular beauty spot in Bury
item.description: Police were called to reports of concern for welfare near the Kirklees Trail, a former railway line linking Greenmount to Bury, at around 1.10am today.

item.title: Kate Middleton hires former British diplomat Hannah Cockburn-Logie as her new private secretary
item.description: According to her LinkedIn profile, Cleethorpes-born Ms Cockburn-Logie took up the full-time post at Kensington Palace - a role that is similar to a chief of staff - at the beginning of this month.

item.title: Top Asian police officer says 'taking the knee is a powerful symbol of hope'
item.description: Metropolitan Police Assistant Commissioner Neil Basu claimed the country is riddled with 'racial bias' which is 'built into the very fabric of our institutions and society'.

item.title: Prison dog handler, 58, wins nearly £100,000 compensation
item.description: A champion prison dog handler has won nearly £100,000 compensation because he was told he couldn't come back to work after his award-winning dog Chester had to be put down.

item.title: UK faces biggest hit from coronavirus of any major economy in the WORLD
item.description: The OECD's latest estimates predict that GDP will nosedive by 11.5 per cent this year, even more than the 11.4 per cent expected in France and 11.3 per cent in Italy.

item.title: Apple could ditch Intel processors for its Macs
item.description: Apple is set to announce plans to ditch Intel processors for its Mac computers at its developers' conference later this month.

item.title: Tiny bone discovered in the hearts of chimpanzees may be a sign of heart disease
item.description: Researchers from the University of Nottingham spotted the bone - which is mere millimetres in length - in micro-CT scans of chimp hearts.

item.title: Coronavirus outbreak has worsened mental health, study says
item.description: The coronavirus pandemic has worsened mental health unlike 'anything seen in recent years', especially for young women, a new study reports.

item.title: How has Covid-19 affected your hometown?
item.description: An interactive graphic created by researchers at the University of Cambridge shows how coronavirus deaths in each area of England and Wales break down by date and place of death.

item.title: Panicking passenger plunges into the water as they try to leap onto a departing ferry
item.description: The passenger is supposed to be travelling from his home in Paramushiro to Kamchatka, Russia. The man tries to fling a bag into the boat but ends up falling in the water.

item.title: Police hunt for family of four after couple vanish with two children
item.description: Charlene Collins, 25, and Martin Collins, 27, and their two children, aged approximately one and two, are missing from the O'Connor Court area of Derry, Northern Ireland.

item.title: More than 500 jobs set to be lost after Monsoon Accessorize entered administration
item.description: British retailer Monsoon Accessorize expects to make 545 staff redundant as it closes 35 stores, and fashion chain Quiz is placing the division that runs its 82 standalone stores into administration.

item.title: Girl who was born with a rare skin condition, signs a contract with a top modelling agency
item.description: Angie, 43, and Kevin, 42, from Washington, whose daughter Harper Foy was diagnosed with Harlequin Ichthyosis, hope that having her sign up to a modelling agency will spread awareness.

item.title: Italian woman, 60, prepares stuffed olives while undergoing brain surgery
item.description: Her actions allowed the surgeons to calibrate their work as they operated on the patient's left temporal lobe at the Azienda Ospedali Riuniti in Ancona.

item.title: Mind blowing video showing how to remove oven glass door in seconds
item.description: An Australian homeowner has revealed how she made her greasy oven door squeaky clean after she discovered a little-known feature that removes the glass in seconds.

item.title: Three more Russian Covid-19 patients fall to deaths from hospital windows
item.description: The three further deaths come amid growing concerns among victims' family members that antibiotic drugs used to treat coronavirus patients are causing suicidal thoughts.

item.title: Frankie and Benny's owner will permanently close 125 restaurants
item.description: The Restaurant Group, which owns Frankie and Benny's, has confirmed plans to close 125 of its sites as it tries to push down rents after the huge hit to the hospitality sector from coronavirus.

item.title: PAUL THOMAS on... Prince Andrew's legal woes
item.description: 'We're waiting for news on the pub reopening - they're here to interview Prince Andrew'
